The triboelectric effect occurs when two different materials come into contact and then separate, causing an exchange of electrons. <[silence]> This electron transfer leads to one material becoming positively charged and the other negatively charged. <[silence]> The phenomenon is influenced by the nature of the materials involved, such as their surface roughness and chemical composition. <[silence]> This effect is commonly observed in everyday life, like when a balloon sticks to a wall after being rubbed against hair. <[silence]>

Historically, the triboelectric effect has been known since ancient times, but its scientific exploration began in earnest in the 18th century. <[silence]> Scientists have developed a triboelectric series, a list ranking materials by their tendency to gain or lose electrons. <[silence]> This series helps predict the outcome of material interactions. <[silence]> Despite its long history, the precise mechanisms at the atomic level are still being studied. <[silence]>

In modern applications, the triboelectric effect is harnessed in triboelectric nanogenerators (TENGs) to convert mechanical energy into electrical energy. <[silence]> These devices have potential in sustainable energy solutions, powering small electronics through everyday motions. <[silence]> Advances in material science have led to more efficient TENG designs, increasing their viability for widespread use. <[silence]> The effect's simplicity and versatility make it a promising area for future research. <[silence]>

Three related subjects are piezoelectricity, electrostatics, and material science.
